Well, the karakusa leaf does remind me of Kaga-Fushimi work.  My sample of ONE
was a 2 inch kojiri on a katana I once had.  I saw similar work in one of Bob
Haynes' catalogues that he called Kaga Fushimi.  That's the beginning and end of
my knowledge on this, except that I do have a Heianjo/Yoshiro zogan tsuba the
same as the one in Gary D. Murtha's Vol 1 (? - maybe Vol 2).  Oh, in Kaga
Fushimi work the leaves were modelled in a copper-like alloy and the veins
incised, so the resemblance in this case is only superficial.  I'm not making an
authoritative statement here...
Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann <swords@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, April 24, 2005 6:15 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] yoshiro school tsuba?



Hi Alan -

Sorry. When I said Kaga and the Yoshiro, I meant Kaga Yoshiro and the Yoshiro of
Kyoto area. (I think that's right, right?)

When thinking Kaga Yoshiro, I've had the impression that more often they would
have squarish-type hitsuana; these are conventional shape with the kogai histsu
being very "rounded/drilled-like" as you see on many of the Kyo-sukashi tsuba.
That was my thinking here. Not sure why, but I also thought Kaga Yoshiro tsuba
were more of a thinner plate than the others, but I'm not sure where that idea
came from.

Ron
STL

  'Kaga Yoshiro' and 'Bizen Yoshiro'.

  Alan
